questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a 10-year history of cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use presents to the emergency department with worsening fatigue, abdominal distension, and confusion over the past two weeks. The patient also mentions reduced urine output for the past 48 hrs. His lab tests reveal a serum creatinine of 2.3 mg/dL, and his urine analysis shows a low sodium concentration. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Hepatorenal syndrome

Pathophysiology

Renal vasoconstriction occurs due to altered systemic vascular resistance in advanced liver disease, leading to functional kidney impairment.

Types

Type 1

Type 2

Progression

Rapid (within 1 - 2 weeks)

Gradual

Clinical parameters

￪Serum creatinine

￬ eGFR and ￪ Serum creatinine, but kidney function is stable comparatively.

Progress

Poor

Comparatively better

Diagnostic factors
  • Presence of large ascites
  • Elevated serum creatinine
  • Low urine sodium concentration
  • Absence of other identifiable causes of renal failure.

Management
  • Withhold diuretics as they can worsen renal perfusion.
  • Albumin infusion: 1 g/kg/day to improve intravascular volume and renal perfusion.
  • Vasoconstrictors: Terlipressin or a combination of midodrine, octreotide, and albumin infusion.
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation. (Option A)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with severe hypertension (BP 220/140 mmHg), headache, and altered mental status. Fundoscopy shows retinal haemorrhages, and laboratory tests indicate elevated serum creatinine. What histopathological finding is most likely seen in the kidney of this patient?

A 3-year-old boy presents with periorbital oedema and leg swelling that began a week ago. Laboratory tests reveal 4+ proteinuria and low serum albumin. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are normal. Light microscopy of a renal biopsy reveals no glomerular lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports episodes of blood in his urine starting two days after a common cold, along with occasional abdominal pain. The child is vitally stable. Investigations show hematuria with normal kidney function tests and C3 levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy)  
Pathophysiology
Clinical features
  • Incidental finding
  • Macroscopic hematuria (recurrent) following an upper respiratory infection (URTI)
  • Asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (persistent)
  • If this patient develops an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI), microscopic hematuria can progress to macroscopic (gross) hematuria within 48 hours.
  • Normal blood pressure
  • Normal urine output
Lab findings
  • Normal values of renal function test (serum creatinine, serum urea, etc.)
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal serum C3 level
Pathological findings

Light microscopy: Mesangial proliferation.

Immunofluorescent microscopy: Mesangial deposition of IgA.
Management
  • There is no optimal treatment, but the following drugs are used:
    • ACE-i (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors) like captopril and enalapril.
    • Steroids (when the patient has recovered from URTI)
    • Fish oil and tonsillectomy are suggested in studies.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the ICU following major cardiac surgery. Post-operatively, his urine output has decreased significantly, raising concerns about acute kidney injury (AKI). Which of the following investigations would be most useful for early detection of AKI in this patient?
questions.explanation:
BIOMARKERS for early detection of AKI

NGAL

Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin

  • Useful for early detection of acute kidney injury (AKI), particularly following cardiopulmonary bypass surgery.
  • It can be measured in both urine and plasma, providing a rapid and sensitive indication of kidney damage before significant changes in traditional markers like serum creatinine are observed.

KIM-1

Kidney injury molecule - 1

  • Type 1 transmembrane protein in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the kidney, upregulated in response to injury.
  • Tested in urine and plasma

suPAR

Soluble urokinase plasminogen-activating receptor

  • Signalling glycoprotein.
  • Tested in only plasma.

IGFBP7

Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7 and tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2 are being used as predictive biomarkers for the high risk of development of moderate to severe AKI in critically ill patients.

TIMP-2

Biomarkers for early detection of AKI
  • NGAL (Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin)
  • KIM-1 (Kidney injury molecule - 1)
  • suPAR (Soluble urokinase plasminogen-activating receptor)
  • IGFBP7 (Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7)
  • TIMP-2 (Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with worsening fatigue, leg swelling, and occasional shortness of breath. He has a 15-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatinine and a reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Which of the following diseases is least likely to have caused his condition?
questions.explanation:
CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE

Risk factors

  • Chronic systemic diseases
    • Diabetes and metabolic syndromes
    • Autoinflammatory disorders: SLE, Vasculitis
    • Infections: HIV, HBV, HCV
    • Toxic exposure: Antineoplastic agents
    • Hypertension
  • Lifestyle
    • Smoking
    • Diet
    • Physical activity

Leading causes

  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Hypertension
  • Ischemic heart disease (Cardiorenal syndrome)
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Tubulointerstitial kidney disease

Manifestation

  • Weight loss
  • Nausea
  • Hiccups (urea irritates gastric mucosa)
  • Pedal oedema
  • Muscle cramping and twitching
  • Pruritus and skin pigmentation
  • Uremic fetor
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Uremic pericarditis
  • Hypertension

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is evaluated for hemodialysis. The patient presents with fluid overload, hyperkalemia, and significant lethargy. Which of the following is not an indication for initiating hemodialysis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Indication

Acute (AKI)

Chronic(CKD)

Fluid Overload
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Severe Hypertension
  • Edema resistant to diuretics

Hyperkalemia
  • >6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes (Broad QRS)
  • Potassium resistant to treatment

Uraemia
  • Pericarditis
  • Encephalopathy
  • Uremic syndrome (anorexia, nausea, lethargy, etc.), typically when eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m²

Metabolic Acidosis
  • Severe acidosis

(H+ > 79 nmol/L; pH < 7.1)
  • Chronic acidosis resistant to bicarbonate therapy

Relative indications
  • Bleeding diathesis due to uremia-induced platelet dysfunction
  • Intractable anemia despite erythropoietin and iron supplementation
  • Hyperphosphatemia despite phosphate binders

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes presents with fatigue, mild shortness of breath, decreased urine output, increased lethargy, and mild ankle swelling. His vital signs show BP 140/85 mmHg and HR 88 bpm. He has been diagnosed with Stage 1 acute kidney injury (AKI). What is the expected elevation in serum creatinine levels for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Staging of the severity of AKI

Stages

Serum creatinine

Urine output

Stage 1

1.5–1.9 times baseline (Option C)

(OR)

≥0.3 mg/dL (≥26.5 μmol/L) increased

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for 6–12 hours

Stage 2

2.0–2.9 times baseline (Option B)

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for ≥12 hours

Stage 3

≥3.0 times baseline (Option A)

(OR)

Serum creatinine increase by ≥4.0 mg/dL (≥353.6 μmol/L)

(OR)

Initiation of renal replacement therapy

(OR)

In patients <18 years of age, there is a decrease in eGFR to <35 mL/min per 1.73 metre square.

<0.3 mL/kg/hr for ≥24 hours

(OR)

Anuria for ≥12 hours

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic heart failure (CHF) and hypertension presents with 2 days of worsening fatigue, decreased urine output, and mild confusion. He appears dehydrated with ankle oedema. His BP is 85/55 mmHg, HR is 102 bpm, and serum creatinine is 2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL). Which of the following antihypertensives is considered safe in this condition?

A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family due to 2 days of persistent vomiting, nausea, confusion, and deep, rapid breathing. Her family reports that she has been lethargic and disoriented, with increasing difficulty responding to questions. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Based on the lab findings given below, identify the type of metabolic disorder. Blood pH - 7.28 Sodium - 140 mEq/L Potassium - 5.4 mEq/L Bicarbonate - 10 mEq/L Chloride - 98 mEq/l pCO2 - 22 mm hg pO2 - 95 mmHg RBS - 382 mg/dL
questions.correct_answer: A. High anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

High anion gap

Non-anion gap

  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia: AKI, CKD
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol poisoning
  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Hyperchloremia
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhoea and conditions causing GI loss of HCO3- (ureterosigmoidostomy or external bowel drainage)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone and K-sparing diuretics
  • Saline infusion (rapid infusion )

Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up, reporting fatigue and mild lower extremity oedema. Examination reveals blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg and abdominal mass. Radiological investigation indicates bilateral kidney enlargement. Which of the following is not a cause of bilateral kidney enlargement?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Renal Enlargement

Bilateral

Unilateral

Can be either
  • Diabetic nephropathy (most common)
  • HIV nephropathy (FSGS)
  • Amyloidosis
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Leukaemia
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Acromegaly
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal artery infarction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Acute pyelonephritis
  • Renal lymphoma

questions.text: Match the following renal stones with their microscopic appearance, 1. Calcium oxalate dihydrate a. 2. Calcium phosphate b. 3. Struvite stone c. 4. Cystine stone d.
questions.explanation:
Calcium oxalate

  • Most common type of renal stone.
  • Types: Monohydrate and dihydrate forms
  • Causes: Hypercalciuria (most common), hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, hypocitraturia.
  • Microscopic appearance:
    • Monohydrate crystals: Dumbbell or picket fence appearance
    • Dihydrate crystals: Envelope shaped

 

Calcium phosphate

  • Causes: Renal tubular acidosis Type I, primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Microscopic appearance: Rosette-shaped crystals
  

Uric acid stone

  • These crystals are soft, break easily, and can adopt any shape.
  • Caused by conditions resulting in hyperuricosuria (gout).
  

Cystine stone

  • They are the hardest stones.
  • Causes: Cystinuria, cystinosis (inborn metabolic error, causes death in 1st year of life)
  • Microscopic appearance: Hexagonal shape
 

Struvite stones or Staghorn calculi

  • Also known as triple phosphate stone (MgNH4Po4)
  • Caused by recurrent UTI (urinary tract infection)
  • Causative organism: Proteus mirabilis.
  • Microscopic appearance: Coffin-lid appearance of crystals.
  

Ciprofloxacin stones

  • Stellate shaped
  

Amoxicillin stones

  • Broom shaped

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with hypertension presents with severe left flank pain, nausea, and hematuria, his third episode in a year. A CT scan shows a 2.8 cm stone in the left ureter and several smaller stones in the left kidney. What is the preferred surgical method and prevention strategy? PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy ESWL: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy
questions.explanation:
Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). (Option C, D)
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. (Option B)
  • Uretrorenoscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

Type of stone

Preventive measures

Calcium oxalate stones
  • Maintain normal calcium intake (1200mg/dL)
  • Low sodium intake
  • Low animal protein intake
  • Thiazide (Chlorthalidone)
  • DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet

Calcium phosphate stones
  • Low sodium diet
  • Thiazide (chlorthalidone)
  • Alkali supplementation (potassium citrate or bicarbonate)

Uric acid stones
  • Alkalisation of urine and maintaining urine pH 6.5 (by increasing fruits and vegetables in the diet, cutting off animal protein, and, if needed, alkali supplements)
  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitor (Allopurinol or Febuxostat) to prevent uricosuria

Cystine stones
  • Tiopronin (preferred) or penicillamine
  • Alkalisation of urine to pH 7.5 (potassium citrate or bicarbonate)

Struvite stones
  • Treat the infection (antibiotics)
  • Acetohydroxamic acid

questions.text: Match the following urine sodium concentration values to the likely correct cause of acute kidney injury (AKI): Urine Sodium Concentration (mEq/L) Type of AKI 1. < 20 mEq/L a. Renal AKI 2. > 40 mEq/L b. Pre-renal AKI 3. 20 - 40 mEq/L c. Post-renal AKI
questions.explanation:
Feature

Pre-Renal AKI

Renal (Intrinsic) AKI

Post-Renal AKI

Cause

Impaired renal perfusion

Direct kidney damage (e.g., ATN, glomerulonephritis)

Obstruction of urinary tract

Pathophysiology

Decreased blood flow to kidneys

Damage to kidney structures (e.g., tubules, glomeruli)

Urine backflow due to obstruction

Urine Sodium

< 20 mEq/L (conserving sodium)

> 40 mEq/L (impaired sodium reabsorption)

Variable, often normal(20-40 mEq/L) or slightly low

FENa

< 1% (kidneys conserve sodium)

> 2% (impaired tubular reabsorption)

Usually normal

Urine Osmolality

> 500 mOsm/kg (concentrated urine)

< 350 mOsm/kg (dilute urine)

Variable

BUN/ Creatinine Ratio

> 20:1 (indicates dehydration or low perfusion)

10-20:1 (or normal)

Normal or mildly elevated

Treatment
  • Fluid replacement (IV fluids for hypovolemia)
  • Address the underlying cause(e.g., volume resuscitation for dehydration, inotropes for heart failure, stopping nephrotoxic drugs).
  • Address the underlying cause(e.g., discontinuing nephrotoxic drugs, treating infection or glomerulonephritis).
  • Supportive care(e.g., dialysis in severe cases, fluid management, electrolyte correction).
  • Relieve the obstruction: Catheterization for bladder outlet obstruction, surgery or lithotripsy for urinary stones, or stent placement for ureteral obstructions.
  • Address any infection- Antibiotics (e.g., urinary tract infection, pyelonephritis).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes presents with worsening proteinuria. Her urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. A subsequent 24-hour urine collection was done, and possible glomerular disease was suspected. What is the estimated protein quantity for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Urine Dipstick test

Significance

It is a rapid and cost-effective tool for screening and monitoring various urinary abnormalities, aiding in the early detection of kidney and systemic diseases.

Disadvantages

  • Paraproteins (+ve charged protein) like Bence Jones proteins are missed in dipstick.
  • The dipstick primarily detects albumin (a -ve charged protein), the most common urine protein, and may also identify other proteins, but in smaller amounts.
  • Results can be affected by factors such as urine pH, concentration, and temperature, leading to inconsistent readings.

Interpretation

Comparing the colour changes on each reagent pad to the provided colour chart on the dipstick packaging helps in assessing parameters like

  • Proteins
  • Glucose
  • Ketones
  • Blood
  • pH
  • Nitrites
  • Leukocyte Esterase

Normal range of Proteinuria
  • Normal proteinuria in adults is <150mg/day
  • Glomerular Proteinuria is <30mg/day
  • Proteins from tubules are around 120 mg/day (Tamm Horsfall proteins/Uromodulin)


 

Values of Proteinuria

Dipstick Reading

PCR

Significance

nil

< 25 mg/mmol

Normal

nil

25 - 50 mg/mmol

Moderate albuminuria

1+ to 2+

50 - 100 mg/mmol

Positive dipstick

2+ to 3+

100 - 350 mg/mmol

Possible glomerular disease, i.e.> 1g protein in a day

3+ to 4+

> 350 mg/mmol

Nephrotic range, i.e. > 3.5 g protein in a day

Proteinuria in Dipstick

Protein Quantity

Trace

15-30 mg/dl

1+

30-100 mg/dl

2+

100-300 mg/dl

3+

300-1000 mg/dl

4+

>1000 mg/dl

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of generalised oedema, significant fatigue, and an increased weight over the past month; he mentions that he has recently noticed his urine appearing foamy. Urine Dipstick: 4+ for protein 24-Hour urine Protein: 5000 mg Serum Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL What is the most likely underlying cause, considering these lab parameters?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Nephrotic range Proteinuria
  • Diabetic nephropathy
  • Minimal change disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Amyloidosis
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Disease

Associations

Serologic Tests

Minimal Change

Allergy, atopy, NSAIDs, Hodgkin’s

None

Focal Sclerosing Glomerulosclerosis

African Americans, HIV, Heroin

HIV Ab

Membranous

Drugs: gold, penicillamine, NSAIDs, Lupus Nephritis, Malignancy: breast, lung, GI

Hep B surface antigen, Hep C antibody, Anti-DNA Ab

Membranoproliferative GN Type I

C4 Nephritic factor

C3↓, C4↓

Membranoproliferative GN Type II

C3 Nephritic factor

C3↓, C4 normal

Cryoglobulinemic MPGN

Hepatitis C

Anti-HCV antibody, rheumatoid factor, C3↓, C4↓, CH 50↓

Amyloidosis

Myeloma, Rheumatoid arthritis, bronchiectasis, Crohn’s disease, FMF

SPEP, UPEP

Diabetic Nephropathy

Other diabetic microangiopathy

None

questions.text: A 32-year-old female visits her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She feels well and has no specific concerns. Routine investigations reveal her urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.032. What is the most likely cause of this finding?

A 60-year-old man with a long-standing history of bipolar disorder, treated with lithium, presents with polyuria and polydipsia. He complains of waking up multiple times at night to urinate. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum sodium and osmolality with dilute urine. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinuation of lithium and initiation of a low-sodium diet

options.label: D
options.text: Fluid restriction to 1 litre per day

questions.correct_answer: B. Discontinuation of lithium and initiation of a low-sodium diet

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a regular annual check-up. Her blood tests reveal a serum bicarbonate level of 12 mEq/L, serum potassium of 3.2 mEq/L, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Urine pH is 5.2, and aminoaciduria and glycosuria are detected despite normal blood glucose levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type 2 Renal tubular acidosis  
Defect

Defective HCO3- reabsorption in the PCT ➜ Metabolic acidosis
Serum electrolytes

Hypokalemia

Due to ￪ HCO3⁻ loss ➜ Higher sodium delivery to the distal tubule ➜ Increased potassium excretion ➜ Hypokalemia
Urine changes Glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome) pH< 5.5
Causes
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Wilson's disease
  • Multiple myeloma (Paraproteinaemia)
  • Heavy metals (Lead, cadmium, mercury)
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Tenofovir, topiramate
  • Expired tetracycline
  • Galactosemia
  • Cystinosis
  • Cisplatin therapy
Association Hypophosphatemic rickets in Fanconi syndrome
Treatment

Oral sodium bicarbonate

Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came to OP with a fever, weakness of the right side of her body, and bleeding episodes while brushing. Preliminary investigations revealed S.Creatinine: 2 mg/dL (0.6-1.1 mg/dl) Platelet count: 20,000 cells/cu.mm (1,50,000-4,00,000 cells/cu.mm) Bleeding time: 10 mins (2-7 mins) PT: 15 sec (11.5-13.5 seconds) aPTT: 38 sec (21-35 seconds) Peripheral smear revealed the following  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
ITP (Option A ruled out)

TTP (Option C)

HSP (Option A ruled out)

DIC (Option A ruled out)

Age
  • Child (5-15 y)
  • Middle-aged females (20-40y)
  • Middle-aged females >> males
  • Children usually in the first decade
  • No specific age predominance

Cause
  • Autoimmune causes
  • Associated with autoimmune diseases - mainly SLE.
  • Infections: HIV, Hep-C, H.pylori
  • Deficiency/autoantibodies to ADAMTS-13
  • ADAMTS-13 is responsible for cleaving vWF.
  • Deficiency of ADAMTS-13 leads to ↑ vWF levels.
  • IgA-mediated Vasculitis - blood vessels are affected, and platelets are spared
  • Sepsis
  • Trauma
  • Malignancy (AML-M3)
  • Obstetric: Abruptio placenta, amniotic fluid embolism

Clinical features
  • Fever + thrombo- cytopenia
  • Self-resolving in children
  • May cause bleeding manifestations in adults
  • Fever + thrombo- cytopenia
  • MAHA
  • Stroke
  • AKI/CKD
  • Non thrombo- cytopenic Purpura
  • Fever
  • AKI (rarely)
  • Low platelet counts with bleeding manifestations + hypotensive shock
   

C3 - Normal (N)

Fibrinogen - N

Fibrinogen - ↓

BT

↑

N

↑

↑

PT

N

N

N/ minor ↑

↑

aPTT

N

N

N/ minor ↑

↑

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be a case of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 cysts in one kidney of a 20-year-old

options.label: B
options.text: 2 cysts in each kidney of a 36-year-old

options.label: C
options.text: 4 cysts in each kidney of a 67-year-old

options.label: D
options.text: 2 cysts in one kidney of a 30-year-old

questions.correct_answer: D. 2 cysts in one kidney of a 30-year-old
questions.explanation:
Investigations
  • Renal Ultrasonography.
    • Non-invasive, used for presymptomatic screening and donor evaluation.
    • Limited sensitivity for PKD2 mutation due to late-onset; may miss smaller cysts.
  • CT Scan
    • More sensitive than ultrasound for detecting smaller cysts.
  • T2-MRI (With/Without Contrast)
    • Detects cysts as small as 2–3 mm using gadolinium contrast.
    • Minimal renal toxicity compared to CT contrast agents.
    • Some cysts may remain undetected even with MRI.
  • Genetic Testing
    • Used in ambiguous cases or atypical presentations.
    • Next-generation sequencing reduces costs and improves sensitivity.
    • PKD1 gene testing is complex and expensive due to the presence of pseudogenes.

Management
  • Blood Pressure Control
    • ACE inhibitors or ARBs
 
  • Antibiotic Treatment for Cyst Infections
    • Preferred Antibiotics: Lipid-soluble (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones, chloramphenicol)
    • Duration: 4–6 weeks
 
  • Kidney Stone Management
    • Hydration
    • Analgesics for pain relief
 
  • Pain management:
  • Analgesics
  • Surgical Cyst Decompression
  • Nerve Block
 
  • Dialysis and Transplantation:
    • Dialysis Options: Peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis
    • Challenges with Peritoneal Dialysis: Limited intra-abdominal space, increased risk of hernia and back pain
    • Pre-transplant Nephrectomy: May be needed for large kidneys or recurrent infections to accommodate the graft
 
  • Medications to Slow Disease Progression:
    • mTOR Inhibitors: Sirolimus, everolimus
    • V2R Antagonists: Tolvaptan
    • Somatostatin Analogues: Octreotide-LAR
    • Combination Therapy: Enhances efficacy, reduces side effects

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents in the Emergency Department with palpitations and muscle fasciculations. The ECG shows tall T waves and a prolonged QT interval. Serum electrolytes: Na—136 mEq/l; K—6.2 mEq/l. What is the next immediate step in the management of this patient?
A 56-year-old male presenting with seizures has a serum magnesium level of 0.5 mmol/L. What is the most likely ECG finding?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Clinical Features Tetany Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes) Central nervous system excitation and seizure Vasoconstriction and hypertension Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out) , T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out) , ST straightening (Option B) Management Identify and treat the underlying cause. IV magnesium chloride: Administer at a rate of ≤0.5 mmol/kg in the first 24 hours. IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible. Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea. If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.
  • ↳ Clinical Features Tetany Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes) Central nervous system excitation and seizure Vasoconstriction and hypertension Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out) , T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out) , ST straightening (Option B)
  • ↳ Clinical Features
  • ↳ Clinical Features
  • ↳ Clinical Features
  • ↳ Tetany Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes) Central nervous system excitation and seizure Vasoconstriction and hypertension Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out) , T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out) , ST straightening (Option B)
  • ↳ Tetany Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes) Central nervous system excitation and seizure Vasoconstriction and hypertension Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out) , T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out) , ST straightening (Option B)
  • ↳ Tetany
  • ↳ Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes)
  • ↳ Central nervous system excitation and seizure
  • ↳ Vasoconstriction and hypertension
  • ↳ Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia
  • ↳ ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out) , T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out) , ST straightening (Option B)

  • ↳ (Option B)

IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible. Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea. If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.
  • ↳ Management
  • ↳ Management

  • ↳ Identify and treat the underlying cause. IV magnesium chloride: Administer at a rate of ≤0.5 mmol/kg in the first 24 hours. IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible. Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea. If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.
  • ↳ Identify and treat the underlying cause. IV magnesium chloride: Administer at a rate of ≤0.5 mmol/kg in the first 24 hours. IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible. Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea. If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.
  • ↳ Identify and treat the underlying cause.
  • ↳ IV magnesium chloride: Administer at a rate of ≤0.5 mmol/kg in the first 24 hours.
  • ↳ IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible.
  • ↳ Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea.
  • ↳ If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.

Clinical Features
  • Tetany
  • Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsades de pointes)
  • Central nervous system excitation and seizure
  • Vasoconstriction and hypertension
  • Associated with hyponatremia and hypokalemia
  • ECG abnormalities: prolonged PR or QT intervals (Option C and D ruled out), T-wave flattening/inversion (Option A ruled out), ST straightening (Option B)

Management
  • Identify and treat the underlying cause.
  • IV magnesium chloride: Administer at a rate of ≤0.5 mmol/kg in the first 24 hours.
  • IM magnesium sulfate: Alternative if IV access is not possible.
  • Oral magnesium salts: Limited effectiveness due to poor absorption and potential diarrhoea.
  • If caused by diuretic use, potassium-sparing agents can help reduce urinary magnesium loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who has been diagnosed with a Parathyroid gland malignancy was brought to ED with acute onset low levels of consciousness and severe pain in the abdomen. Her vitals were HR- 56 bpm, BP- 88/64 mmHg. ECG done showed a shortened QT interval. Serum Ca2+ (calcium)- 13 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate first step in managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
1) Adequate hydration
  • 4-6 L of IV Normal saline over the first 24 hours and body water must be replenished.
  • First step in management

2) Loop diuretics
  • Like Furosemide must be given IV, but only after correcting body fluid status (Option B)

3) Bis- phosphonates
  • DOC for hypercalcemic crisis - mainstay of treatment (Option D)
  • IV Zoledronate 4 mg
  • IM Pamidronate 60 mg
  • The onset of action: 1-3 days (hence not suitable in acute presentations)

4) Steroids
  • Mainly useful in Malignancy, sarcoidosis, and Vitamin D intoxication (Option C)

5) Others
  • Salmon calcitonin:
    • Given as nasal spray
    • Rapid onset of action
    • ADR: Tachyphylaxis
  • Denosumab: Monoclonal antibody against RANK-ligand and prevents its binding to RANK receptor on osteoclasts
  • Gallium nitrate: alternative to Bisphosphonates, ADR- Nephrotoxic
  • Hemodialysis: rarely required

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of congestive heart failure on ACE inhibitors presents to the emergency department with symptoms of weakness and palpitations. On examination, there were signs of elevated JVP and bounding pulse. The ECG findings of the patient suggest tall T waves and wide QRS complex. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
Which of the following is not a cause of hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation:
Increased Potassium Intake
  • Increased potassium intake from food is a very uncommon cause of hyperkalemia in adult patients with normal renal function but can be an important cause in those with kidney disease.

Intracellular Potassium Shifts
  • Cellular injury
  • Metabolic acidosis (Option C)
  • Sepsis
  • Dehydration
  • Insulin deficiency
  • Diabetic Ketoacidosis
  • Tumor lysis syndrome (Option B)
  • Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
  • Medications such as Succinylcholine (Option A)

Impaired Potassium Excretion
  • Acute or chronic kidney disease is a common cause of hyperkalemia.
  • Hyperkalemia is usually not seen until the glomerular filtration rate falls below 30 ml/min.
  • Tubular dysfunction due to aldosterone deficiency.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness, fatigue, and occasional palpitations for the past few days. She has a history of congestive heart failure and is on furosemide for fluid management. On physical examination, she appears mildly dehydrated. ECG findings are given below. What is the most likely electrolyte abnormality in this patient?

A 55-year-old female with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with muscle weakness and palpitations. What is the most likely acid-base disturbance, given the patient's serum potassium and bicarbonate levels? Laboratory results reveal the following: Serum potassium: 6.5 mEq/L Serum bicarbonate: 15 mEq/L

A 60-year-old male weighing 60 kg is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of confusion and seizures. Blood investigations revealed a serum sodium level of 125 mEq/L. You aim to calculate the total sodium deficit that needs to be corrected to bring his serum sodium to a target of 135 mEq/L. What is the total sodium deficit (in mEq) that needs to be corrected in this patient?
Values of serum Sodium and plasma Osmolality are, Na+: 130 mEq/L Osmolality: 310 mOsm/L Which among the following clinical scenarios is least likely to cause this derangement?

options.label: A
options.text: A 60-year male with blood glucose > 500 mg/dL upon arrival

options.label: B
options.text: Patient developing headache and dizziness post-MRI with contrast

options.label: C
options.text: Exogenous infusion of mannitol to a patient with a head injury

options.label: D
options.text: A 40 year female excreting > 20 L urine per day with absence of pituitary bright spot on MRI

questions.correct_answer: D. A 40 year female excreting > 20 L urine per day with absence of pituitary bright spot on MRI

questions.text: A 49-year-old lady with hypothyroidism is presenting with nausea and headache. Her serum sodium level is 126 mmol/L. What kind of hyponatremia is this most likely to be?
A 65-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with vomiting and seizures. What is his most probable serum sodium level?
questions.explanation:
Severity

Serum Sodium Level (mmol/L)

Symptoms

Mild

130–135

(Option A ruled out)

(Option D ruled out)

None

Moderate

125–129

(Option B ruled out)

Nausea, Delirium, Headache

Severe

< 124

(Option C)

Vomiting, Somnolence, Seizures, Coma, Cardiorespiratory arrest

questions.text: Match the following conditions to their underlying mechanisms. Conditions Mechanisms A) Gitelman Syndrome 1. Increased mineralocorticoid activity B) Conn's Syndrome 2. Inhibition of sodium-chloride cotransporter C) Bartter Syndrome 3. Loop of Henle dysfunction D) Diuretic Abuse 4. Induced loss of electrolytes E) Liddle Syndrome 5. Gain of function mutation in epithelial sodium channels
questions.explanation:
Redistribution into cells

Presenting Condition

Description

Insulin
  • Insulin promotes cellular potassium uptake.
  • Excess insulin, especially during the treatment of potassium-deficient states like diabetic ketoacidosis, can lead to hypokalemia.

Increased β2-adrenergic sympathetic activity

(Epinephrine)

Conditions such as alcohol withdrawal, hyperthyroidism, acute myocardial infarction, and severe head injury increase sympathetic nervous system activity, promoting cellular potassium uptake and hypokalemia.

β2-adrenergic agonists

Medications like bronchodilators and tocolytics stimulate cellular potassium uptake, potentially causing hypokalemia.

α-adrenergic antagonists

These medications can lead to hypokalemia.

Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis

It involves periodic attacks of muscle weakness due to profound hypokalemia, often accompanied by hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia.

Theophylline and Caffeine

These substances can activate cAMP-dependent signalling, leading to hypokalemia, usually in cases of overdose or significant over-ingestion.
